verses.text: But understand this: In the last days there will come times of difficulty.
verses.comment: Paul warns Timothy of future hardships, connecting to prophecies of increasing wickedness before Christ's return. The phrase 'last days' indicates the final era before God's ultimate intervention.

verses.text: For people will be lovers of themselves, lovers of money, boastful, arrogant, abusive, disobedient to parents, ungrateful, unholy,
verses.comment: A long list of sinful behaviors, similar to Romans 1. Notably, Paul includes 'disobedient to parents,' highlighting the importance of the family as a foundation of faith and order.

verses.text: unloving, unforgiving, slanderous, without self-control, brutal, not loving good,
verses.comment: This verse further describes the breakdown of charity and goodness among people. The lack of self-control points to a need for virtues instilled through grace and practice in communal worship.

verses.text: treacherous, reckless, conceited, lovers of pleasure rather than lovers of God,
verses.comment: Paul contrasts worldly pleasure with a love for God. The spiritual path requires discipline and self-offering, as seen in the saints throughout history.

verses.text: having a form of godliness but denying its power. Avoid such people as these.
verses.comment: Outward religion without inner transformation is warned against. Genuine faith is more than appearance; it involves true participation in the power of God dispensed through the sacraments and the apostolic teaching.

verses.text: For among them are those who creep into households and capture weak women, burdened with sins and led astray by various passions,
verses.comment: Paul warns about false teachers taking advantage of the vulnerable. This underscores the importance of sound doctrine and the protective role of church leadership and community.

verses.text: always learning but never able to come to the knowledge of the truth.
verses.comment: True knowledge involves not just information but assent to the truth revealed by God. Conversion is both intellectual and spiritual, found within the stability of apostolic doctrine.

verses.text: Just as Jannes and Jambres opposed Moses, so these men also oppose the truth—men corrupted in mind and disqualified regarding the faith.
verses.comment: Jannes and Jambres were Egyptian magicians who resisted Moses (not named in Old Testament, but cited in Jewish tradition). Paul uses their example to warn of resisting legitimate authority and truth handed down from God.

verses.text: But they will not progress much further, for their folly will be obvious to all, just as it was with those men.
verses.comment: Ultimately, the truth prevails over error. God promises to reveal and judge all things in the light of Christ and His Church.

verses.text: But you have followed my teaching, my conduct, my purpose, my faith, my patience, my love, my endurance,
verses.comment: Paul presents himself as a model for Timothy. Discipleship involves not only beliefs but imitation of holy living—a pattern found in the continuity of apostolic tradition.

verses.text: my persecutions and sufferings—what happened to me at Antioch, at Iconium, and at Lystra—which persecutions I endured. Yet from all of them the Lord rescued me.
verses.comment: Paul’s suffering for the Gospel mirrors Christ’s own passion. God delivers those who stand firm, and trials are a sign of authentic discipleship.

verses.text: Indeed, all who desire to live a godly life in Christ Jesus will be persecuted.
verses.comment: Persecution is expected for those faithful to Christ. This echoes Jesus’ teaching in the Beatitudes and as an ongoing aspect of Christian life.

verses.text: But evil people and impostors will go from bad to worse, deceiving and being deceived.
verses.comment: There is an expectation that false teachers and deceivers will be present, emphasizing the need for discernment and steadfastness in the true apostolic teaching.

verses.text: But as for you, continue in what you have learned and firmly believed, knowing from whom you learned it
verses.comment: Timothy is urged to remain steadfast in the faith passed down to him—echoing the tradition handed on in the early church and preserved through apostolic succession.

verses.text: and how from childhood you have known the sacred writings, which are able to make you wise for salvation through faith in Christ Jesus.
verses.comment: The sacred writings (Old Testament) point to salvation and Christ. Reading Scripture within the inheritance of the faith leads to wisdom and salvation, especially when joined with community and tradition.

verses.text: All Scripture is God-breathed and useful for teaching, for rebuking, for correcting, and for training in righteousness,
verses.comment: Inspired Scripture has a central role in doctrine and formation. The function of the Word is lived out in the context of visible authority, safeguarding right teaching and interpretation.

verses.text: so that the man of God may be complete, equipped for every good work.
verses.comment: The Scriptures prepare believers for holiness and service. Yet, completeness is found in being equipped not only with the Bible but in the whole life of faith, handed on and lived out together in the one Church founded by Christ.
